replies.context: Only the parts of the video you see.

The FBI incited the trespassing event hoping to parlay it into something more dramatic, like "overthrowing the government."  The FBI thinks its role is shaping public opinion at all costs - purely political.  The FBI long ago ceased to be a law-enforcement agency, if it ever really was.

Evidence? And Ray Epps 2 ain't it. I read/watched it. It would be laughed out of court.
discovery is applicable to a prosecution, not an investigation.
I guess all of those court cases are just "investigations"? You should try some of that stuff called "education". You're just embarrassing yourself...
court cases are classified as prosecutions.

The investigation leads to prosecution.  If the libs think Trump is guilty of sedition or a supposed coup, where are the charges?  If Trump gets charged, then release ALL video footage.  If the Dems are accurate then they have nothing to worry about.
What a cop out.  I guess the truth hurts, doesn't it?

What do you think is on the videos that we haven't seen yet? What would it be that would change anyone's mind about what happened that day?

And btw, did you see the January 6 special that included much more of the videos that hadn't been shown yet?
A very small fraction of the thousands of hours of video has ever been released or shown. Drink more Kool-Aid...

So funny that you are calling me a cult member!;-) 

I am aware that I haven't seen all those videos, but what I've seen has been enough for me to assess what went on that day. 

But what do you think "they" are hiding by not showing all those videos? Logically, if something happened that would put the entire episode in a different light, don't you think the people IN those videos would have spoken up?

How would the people "IN" those videos know they were "IN" them, if the DOJ has literally thousands of hours of video that they refuse to release, even to defense attorneys exerting discovery? Since what you've seen is a tiny fraction of the whole, selectively released by the DOJ, I would assert that what you think you are "assessing" is exactly what the DOJ wants you to see. I think that until the video is available for all to see (you know, all that transparency the left is always whining about) you can't accurately assess anything.

The people who saw what you imply the government doesn't want us to see would speak up EVEN if they didn't know there were videos! For example, if even ONE person had seen Nancy Pelosi yelling on the phone, "Do not send the National Guard!" that person would be speaking up, saying, "Show us the videos near her office!" 

Regardless, I don't need to see the thousands of hours of footage from the hundreds of cameras to know what happened that day. Nothing I would see would change my mind about what I saw. I believe my lying eyes here;-). 

Why don't you? What could you possibly see that would change your mind?

P.S. In September of 2021, a judge ordered the government to release surveillance videos of the Capitol Building. Do you have any sources that indicate how many videos were NOT released? I can't find that info.

It has been widely reported by multiple defense attorneys that the DOJ has steadfastly refused to release video when requested. You can easily research the individual cases. This is in direct conflict with longstanding rulings guaranteeing discovery info to be given to the defense prior to trial, otherwise you just end up with "trial by ambush". 
There are multiple witnesses that were present on 1/6 that have given statements that some capitol police allowed protestors in, and some actually held doors for them. Have you seen that video? 
What I've seen of the video has has been selectively released is a bunch of knuckleheads acting stupidly, that need to prosecuted for any criminal violations. I've also seen other "protestors" that were just walking around taking pictures, many of them also arrested, jailed for many months without bail, and prosecuted for extremely minor, low-level crimes and then convicted and sentenced to inordinately long sentences for what would be a very minor misdemeanor in state court. What I have yet to see is any indication of an "armed insurrection" or any attempt to "overthrow the government", or anything else to support the outlandish hyperbole blathered about the crazies on the left and on the blatantly politicized "January 6 Committee".

Thanks. I'll look into those claims about defense not having access to the videos as well as the claims that people have been arrested, jailed, and given long sentences for minor offenses.

RE the videos you mention, YES, I saw all those videos on or right after January 6. Police standing by while people walked in (not sure about seeing them holding the door open), people standing around taking pics, et cetera. I am aware that many people were just swept along in the moment without having the nefarious intent that others did. And I'm hopeful that they would receive a light sentence (for trespassing) or none at all. But those who fought with police, destroyed property, or literally broke in to the building should all be convicted, IMO.

However, the intent of those in charge (Trump & Co, Proud Boys, Oathkeepers) was definitely to interfere with the election such that Donald Trump would remain president. Those people were literally insurrectionists by deed and intent, even if the mob in totality didn't reflect that. Now, were some of the violent members of the crowd just angry that the "vote had been stolen"? Undoubtedly. But that doesn't take anything away from the literal insurrectionists.

We'll have to agree to disagree about the "insurrection". I don't think anything that happened there meets the statutory description of "Insurrection", probably why even the left-leaning, highly politicized DOJ has not charged anyone with it. 
My personal opinion is that there is a lot of evidence that there was some election interference. Was it enough to change the outcome? Who knows...the left has consistently stonewalled any investigations into election interference. Once conservatives take back the House, I hope the GOP has the drive and will to play hardball with the leftists and run some actual investigations, not the political grandstanding characteristic of the left.

Always nice to have a good discussion, though...

Thanks for that; I agree that it is nice to have a good discussion!

I would agree that "insurrection" is a tricky term -- especially since many of the people in the mob were just swept along -- but I do believe that the intention of the folks in charge was to interfere with the official naming of Biden as president . . . so that Trump could somehow be reinstalled instead (fake electors, Pence calling the vote invalid, et cetera).

We see the issue of election interference differently. Why do you say that the left has stonewalled any investigations? I've read the opposite -- that ALL allegations were investigated and found to be completely baseless. The courts said the same thing, including those run by Republican judges.

Cheers!

The issue with "investigations" and "court hearings" is this: no in-depth investigations were ever conducted into any allegations. In some states, the election officials refused to allow interested parties access to voting machines, or to interview election workers. In others, specifically Georgia, democrat workers put up papers and posters to block the view of conservative poll watchers. That has been well-documented. Did it affect the vote counting? Nobody knows because no investigation has ever been held. It was "reviewed" by a democrat "investigator" in Georgia who found that everything was OK. As for the court cases, no case was ever adjudicated. Every court, including SCOTUS, refused to hear anything relating to election interference based on procedural grounds. In other words, no adversarial court hearings to present and rebut evidence were ever held. Those are just a few of the things that make me go HMMMM.
I'm not saying that election interference cost Trump the election, I'm saying that no comprehensive investigation was ever held to determine whether it did or not. Remember, since the election is decided by the Electoral College, how many raw votes either candidate got really doesn't matter, only the electoral votes count . It has been documented that based on the vote tallies, Biden "won" the election by about 45,000 votes, votes that swung electoral votes his way in places like Georgia, Pennsylvania, etc. I think that's why you saw so many really angry people...

Very interesting. My sources (TV, online news) gave me the impression that all the allegations were definitively debunked. Didn't hear about the papers blocking the view, but did hear about all the others. As far as I know, the courts heard the initial evidence/request for a hearing and basically laughed. Sydney Powell even admitted in court that the Dominion Voting Systems "fraud" was so ridiculous that no normal person would believe it. (You might check on the procedural turnaways; I'm pretty sure the courts were turning away the cases for more than just procedure.)

RE Electoral College, I wish we would overturn that dinosaur!

The issue with getting rid of the Electoral College is that then only states like NY and California would elect POTUS. If national elections were decided by the popular vote, then small states would not even count...some blue cities have a larger population than some red states, and vice versa. The Electoral College works to even the playing field, making the candidates have to fight for votes even in the smaller states, otherwise I doubt that candidates would even bother to go to states like Iowa, Montana, Wyoming, etc. The votes there are too few to count against the massive votes in the big states. That's why Biden allegedly had millions more votes than Trump, yet the election was actually decided by around 45,000 votes in the swing states. It is kind of unwieldy, but I think it helps instill some fairness in what might otherwise be a rofflestomp on the less populated states. 

If you haven't watched 2000 Mules, you should give it a try. It might open your eyes to some possibilities.

Gotta head off to work, my friend. Perhaps we can chat again tomorrow...

I know about the rationale for the Electoral College, but I still think that the benefits of election through true majority would be better. In terms of the smaller states being ignored, they might not get as many candidate visits, but they would still have access through the media to all candidate speeches and communiques.
I'm sure it will never happen, but I hope we don't get to the place where the minority has ALL the power. . . .

I read about 2000 Mules. Did you hear about the lawsuit against the makers? I believe it was announced yesterday or today.

I would love to chat again. Thanks for the positive vibes; they are so welcome.

Happy Thursday! The term I've heard before referring to a "true" democracy (1 vote per person) is "the tyranny of the majority". The Electoral College was designed to give the minority a say in picking the Prez. 
I haven't heard about any lawsuits in reference to the movie...I'll have to do some research. Having watched the movie, I can't see anything there that would open any liability to the makers, but in today's litigious-crazy society, I guess pretty much anybody can sue anybody for anything, so I wouldn't be surprised. Prevailing of course, is another matter. If you get a chance, watch it. It may not change your mind or convince you of their premise, but is good food for thought.

Chat again soon...

Good morning! I have heard the same thing about "the tyranny of the majority," but I would rather have a government guided by the opinions of the majority than those of the minority:-)! 

The element that keeps me from shunning a true democracy is the fact that that "majority" is not a fixed entity; the numbers of people will change based on the person they vote for. And their thoughts and feelings will change as well, based on the efficacy of the presidential candidate's presentation, AND the successes or failures of the incumbent. 

Let's say that we had a true democracy in 2016, and Hillary won. After four years, her leadership wasn't all that her voters had hoped, and the majority of the country were more impressed by a Republican's ideas in 2020. They vote for a Republican. . . .

Of course, for a true democracy to occur, we would have to change the way the senate is configured as well since the "two senators per state" doesn't yield true representation. A true representation would currently yield somewhere around 60/40, Democrat/Republican.

Cheers!

The big problem I see would be what if the majority was 51% vs. 49%? The minority is still basically 1/2 of the population...not very much of a majority to be bossed around by the actual "majority". 
That still leaves the problem of the big cities/states, primarily blue, being able to overwhelm smaller cities/states, primarily red. I can see that festering into a recipe for disaster. 
The Senate would be a mess. The actual breakdown is Democrats: 30% of registered voters, Republicans: 24% of registered voters, Independents: 43% of registered voters. Would we have to create a new class just for the Independents, who are the actual "majority"? What a mess that would devolve into...LOL

Good afternoon! To your first point, I'm not sure about the 51% to 49% figure. When looking at generalized ideology, I'm thinking that it's closer to 60% to 40%, or maybe 55% to 45% left-leaning to right-leaning. Hard figure to come to, but I do believe that MOST of the independents lean left. 

To your point about the minority being bossed around by the majority, I come back to my point that this is much better than the major decisions made by the MINORITY who lead 51% to 49% -- something that could easily happen in the next election. (And I'm looking at the Senate here.) But speaking of the Senate, if the new Forward party takes hold, it could help to break up any logjams; I see it as potentially more of a positive rather than the mess you see.

BTW, the actual lopsided percentage with Trump/Clinton was 48% Clinton to 46% Trump, and we know who won. 

RE your cities point, could you explain a bit more? I don't see how a true democracy would negatively impact different sized cities.

Hope you're having a good one!

context:
Just did a search on Google News for "whistleblower + FBI." All the hits were articles from right-leaning, less reputable sources (Washington Examiner, Epoch News, Fox, The Daily Mail, New York Post. . .). My guess is that there's not enough credible evidence yet for the more fact and evidence-based sources to print. [And I'm well aware that some of these less reputable sources occasionally get a scoop, like the NY Post with Hunter's laptop.] 

I'm a wait and see what's up with these whistleblowers and their accusations.

BTW, as I was reading the articles, I came across MANY -- all published on the right-leaning sites listed above and nowhere else -- that NY Times Pulitzer winning reporter Bret Stephens "admitted that the Russian collusion was a hoax." I was shocked since I hadn't heard this, and I have a lot of respect for him. 

So I did a factcheck to try and get to the bottom of it. Lo and behold, I found what I often find with the less reputable sources -- they misinterpret, misinform, and are simply not credible. 

What did Stephens actually say in his July 21 NYT article?  "To this day, precious few anti-Trumpers have been honest with themselves about the elaborate hoax ‚Äî there's just no other word for it ‚Äî that was the Steele dossier and all the bogus allegations, credulously parroted in the mainstream media, that flowed from it." 

As you can see, he's not globalizing to the entire Russian collusion story; he's just talking about the Steele dossier. Ouch.

I respectfully disagree with your first sentence. 

Your statement on Russian collusion is just factually incorrect. Take a look at the Mueller Report and the Senate Investigation.

I respectfully disagree with your disagreement. There is a vast and distinct difference between Russian interference and attempting to influence, both overtly and covertly our election and collusion.
      And Trump, (or his administration colluding with Russia) to influence the outcome of our elections.
Now on some things we may split hairs like on opposition research from foreign sources by someone on behalf of a candidate. But obviously you have to know exactly what the information is and who it is coming from and why it is being offered to you before you can know what is right and wrong about receiving it.
